data.title: Bratislava – Life and Study in the Capital of Slovakia
data.meta_description: Bratislava. Life in Bratislava. Education and universities. Sights and entertainment of the capital of Slovakia
data.text:
The capital of Slovakia, cozy Bratislava, is very popular among tourists and foreign students who come to the country for high education. It is not only the capital of Slovakia but also its the largest city. Bratislava has a rich history, and you can see architectural monuments from different times on its territory, some of them have become museums. The word “Bratislava”, according to the most popular version, is a toponym from the Slovak name Bratislav. Over the long history, the city has changed a number of names:

Preshporok

Pressburg

Pozsony

Istropolis

The Slovak capital is the only capital in the world which has borders with two other states: Austria and Hungary. At the same time, you can get to Austrian Vienna in just an hour. Such proximity to the center of Europe makes this city very attractive for tourists who want to get acquainted with the attraction of several European countries in a few days.

Life in Bratislava

Bratislava is a very comfortable city for permanent residence. Like the rest of Slovakia, it is calm and peaceful, and the inhabitants of the capital are very friendly. Tourists and visitors note that Slovaks are always ready to help in a difficult situation, it’s a well-known fact that the residents of this country are known throughout the world for their friendliness and hospitality.

A big plus is that life in Bratislava is much cheaper than in many other European capitals. Earning an average of 5 euros per hour in their free time, a local student can rent an apartment or live in a hostel. Public transport is also very affordable, especially if you buy an yearly pass. Prices for clothing, food, and entertainment are significantly lower than in other Western European countries, making Slovakia one of the most attractive countries for foreigners in the European Union.

What to see in Bratislava

It doesn’t matter if you are coming with a tour for just a few days or planning to study at one of the Slovak universities – for each visitor we can offer a selection of must-see attractions. They will help you to get to know more about the culture of Slovakia and to learn more about its history from ancient times to the present day. If you still don’t know what to see in Bratislava, take a look at this list.

Religious sites

Most of the residents of Slovakia are Catholics, and their religion has had a huge impact on local architecture. Among the outstanding landmarks closely associated with the Christian faith is St. Martin’s Cathedral. It is famous for the fact that the Roman emperors were once crowned within its walls. The Capuchin Church of St. Stephen is no less famous: modest in terms of architecture, but very aesthetic building once belonged to one of the most famous monastic orders.

Historical monuments

The Old Town is one of the oldest districts in Bratislava. It can rightfully top the list of must-see places for every foreign tourist. The Mikhailovsky Gate, the Grassalkovich Palaceand, the Devin Castle and other buildings can surprise tourists with the beauty of ancient architecture. The Old Town Hall is not just a building with a unique mix of styles – inside it is the City Museum, the exposition of which tells about the history of the city. If tourists want to admire the Danube, we advise them to visit Bratislava Castle, from the observation deck of which a picturesque panorama opens.

Leisure time and recreation

If you feel like getting involved in art, you can visit the Slovak National Theater. All performances in it are staged in the local language, but even without understanding the replicas, the performance looks impressive. It will also be interesting for everyone to see real lynxes, white tigers and antelopes. The history of the Bratislava Zoo goes back over 60 years. Its main goal is to preserve endangered species, but in the large park, children can also get acquainted with the life of prehistoric animals by looking at the figures of dinosaurs.
